text:
1) So thermometers lie....okay
2) So the IPCC is a farce unless it says something you might agree with but don't understand? Like you talk about "the ice is still there" but IPCC reports indicate say the arctic wouldn't be ice-free and only during the summer till 2100, even though it's actually melting faster than the fastest predictions.

> there is no serious science involved and the facts are not real. 
It's basic physics and facts are....facts

> There is no causal proof of C02 being more effective than the 95% greenhouse effect from water vapour.
You do know that the reason why we know it's CO2 based is the basic physics tell us the mechanism right? CO2 absorbs longwave radiation and delays heat dissipation. We can measure the wavelengths absorbed by CO2, we can make predictions of where it will warm the fastest (and cool) based on its physical properties and this is born out in the data. Water vapor wouldn't cool the upper atmosphere, it wouldn't suddenly absorb radiation outside of its absorption bands, it wouldn't be more effective in areas with extremely low water vapor content, water vapor also doesn't drive long-term climate because of the magical process known as condensation.

> There are enough other influences mostly of the sun that are more plausible than CO2.

The suns been flat or cooling for the last 50 years, why would it not only show the physical properties of CO2 based warming as described above, but why would it warm the planet when it's actually less active to the point that people think it might be entering a new maunder minimum type event?

text:
@star cruiser  Very true, Star Cruiser. I'm glad you can see through their junk science with an objective point of view.

 One of the foremost atmospheric scientists in the world, the late Dr. William Gray of Colorado State University, debunked human-caused "global warming," stating it was based on junk science, which took parts of meteorology and climatology out of context and pieced it together to make it say what they wanted it to say. The Dumbocrud "scientists" didn't take into account things like -- the thermohaline conveyer; sunspot cycles (the number of sunspots affect, to a significant degree, the sun's surface temperature); El Niño and La Niña; seasonal hurricane patterns; Earth's magnetic field, which significantly affects global climate; and Earth's many thousands of active volcanoes, calderas and tectonic tears, all which emit more toxic chemicals, smoke and particulates in one month than human industrial activity can produce in FIFTY years! Dumbocruds ignore these factors because they know these factual variables contradict their so-called "facts."

I am a weather spotter and storm chaser, working as a volunteer amateur meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Skywarn program. I have to have more weather training than the average Joe Q. Public (I take recurrent training yearly), I keep my nose in books about meteorology, climatology and forecasting, and I am frequently doing research in these areas. So I can safely say I know about what I speak.

I challenge Dumbocruds to say different... and prove it objectively!! ❗❗😬

text:
+LotusEater its not all about temperature.  the sea level rise is the real threat, and as the temperature heats up, the water expands and absorbs more sunlight.  This causes more c02 to leave the ocean, which will make our problems worse.  In addition, as the c02 levels in the ocean rise, the salinity density levels will change.  This is already impacting coral reefs and other low lying ecosystems.  These ecosystems are already showing signs of rapid collapse and these ecosystems provide food for hundreds of millions of people, if not over a billion.


also, your point about temperature variance in regards to our historical record is misleading as you are not factoring in a critical part... time.  The variances you speak over occurred over hundreds and thousands of years. The little ice age and medieval warming both were created by climate change occurring over 500+ years.   The difference now is the rate of change.  Over our entire atmospheric record from ice cores, we have never seen anything even remotely close to the change we are seeing today.  Carbon changes that took thousands of years just happened in the last 150 years.  It is unprecedented and to write it off as natural phenomenon is dangerous.  I do believe a lot of our change is coming from natural factors, and our earth would of been warming regardless of humans, but we are accelerating the process by thousands of years.  There really is no debate on this subject.  The scientific evidence is overwhelming.

"we would have to outpace all the Volcanic Activity to exceed the Earth's natural output of Carbon"

This statement is wrong on so many levels.

First of all as of 1991 we were already over 135 times the output of all the worlds volcanoes combined and we have had an average yearly rate far greater than then.

https://volcanoes.usgs.gov/hazards/gas/climate.php

Second of all it's not about "outdoing natural emissions" it's disturbing the relative balance of emissions and sequestration. To have this be more clear I'll present you an analogy.

You run a multi billion dollar company with a relatively balanced budget, you might save half a percent more than you spend, but overall it's balanced. I come along and I spend 3% more above your budget for 50 years with compound interest and tell you I can't have an effect because I'm not matching your total budget every year. Does this sound reasonable?

Overall natural emissions and sequestration are about the same, and it's been sequestering more carbon than emitting into the atmosphere, but that changed as we've been emitting ghgs from carbon sources that have taken the earth millions of years to sequester.

@SlipKnotRicky 
"Why is there such a quiet push to change the moniker of Global Warming to Climate Change?"

Shit like this is what I'm talking about, in scientific circles it's always been climate change. That's why it's the IPCC not the IPGW.

Climate change is the scientific term, global warming is the layman's term

" It has always been through cyclical changes and always will be."

This is back to the fire argument and it's relevant because you've proved that you don't even have a basic understanding of the topic. If you don't understand one bit about fire you could make the exact same argument you're making regarding climate change.

"You have not proved your case enough to convince me."

It's hard to convince someone who educates themselves with non sources and doesn't listen to what the science actually has to say on the matter. If you have other people filter what you should think rather than reading the most original sources you can then you'll simply never be convinced of anything you don't want to investigate.

I started off on the skeptics side, I used the same sorts of justifications, what convinced me was looking at the evidence and arguments as presented by the relevant experts and scientific papers myself rather than having their arguments filtered through someone determined to make me believe they're frauds, at which point I may as well have been a creationist denying evolution.

Determining the cause of the most of the warming in recent history is pretty easy. You look at potential mechanisms, you look at how it's warming. Different mechanisms have different ways of warming (and cooling) the fingerprint of how climate is changing is consistent with GHGs, we can measure this in the lowered long wave radiation going out into space, the cooling in the upper atmosphere, we can look at when it's warming and what long term trends are.

We can likewise discount mechanisms by looking at the instrumental record, the sun has been cooling and the sun would warm at the equator faster than the poles so it's not the sun. Cosmic rays don't appear to have any appreciable effect on the climate particularly since correlations broke down in the early 90's and events like the Laschamp anomaly indicate that even if they have any effect on climate that it is no more than a fine tuning knob rather than a significant driver in climate.

If you want to be a good skeptic at least when you're asserting "it's natural" provide a damned mechanism that can be tested. If you don't you may as well be the creationist shrugging their shoulders and saying "it's intelligent design"

text:
@SlipKnotRicky 
I am quite sincere and frankly, as I stated, I was convinced by the physics. Even if we pretend that no paleoclimactic data existed we can still determine what the mechanism is today.

The mechanism of ghgs is also pretty basic, more ghgs delay heat dissipation, a delay in heat dissipation results in more heat for the same given amount of energy. We can determine that ghgs would warm the night as much as the day, we can determine it would warm the troposphere but cool upper layers of the atmosphere, we can determine it will warm the poles quicker than the equator.

We can even determine the primary cause isn't water vapor because it's happening in climates that have low water vapor the quickest. Water vapor also doesn't stay in the atmosphere for very long without warming first.

Frankly speaking if you had nothing else but the instrumental record, looked at the data, and tested the mechanism you don't need anything else to tell you what the most likely cause is and what the causes most certainly aren't.

The reason why I ask for the mechanism is it's the first question you should be asking as a skeptic.

author: Jerome Sullivan

text:
@Jerome Sullivan 
"The current warming is taking place mostly in the lower atmosphere, if it were co2 the warming would take place in the upper atmosphere where there is the most infrared light "

Actually CO2 based warming predicts a cooling in the upper parts of the atmosphere and most of the warming in the troposphere. Which is what we observe. Whoever told you that it should warm the upper part of the atmosphere is severely misinforming you.

CO2 based warming also predicts that it will warm at about the same rate at night as the day, that it will warm at the poles quicker than the equator along with several other predictions which are all observed in the instrumental record. Any proposed mechanism would at bare minimum have to have the same predictive power.

"they know it has a lot to do with the sun..."

Whoever "they" is. The sun's luminosity has been getting lower over the last 50 years so as far as that's concerned the sun has a relative cooling effect the last few solar cycles. Sunspots correlation broke down during the early 90's. Events like the laschamp anomaly indicate that cosmic rays don't have a significant effect on the long term climate.

"We know it is not co2 because it has been warming for 200 years and co2 only began to spike around 1950. "

AGW only deals with around the later half of the century because that's when temperatures started to rise independent of natural markers like solar activity and was predicted to rise outside of what could be dismissed as background noise during the 90's which was observed.

"Are you familiar with the term, 'the pause'?"

Are you familiar with all of the markers that we've been going through for several decades that act as a cooling forcing between the dimming sun, the extra pollution blocking sunlight from hitting the earth or the extra volcanic activity releasing sulfates in the atmosphere?  Are you also familiar with this "pause" starting at a time when we had the strongest el nino on record combined with a near solar maximum, but apparently now that's supposed to be the new average because reasons?

Are you also familiar with the fact that the oceans have been continuing to rise and heat up. This is often ignored to only pay attention to average surface temperatures despite the fact that most of the earth is covered in water and pretending thermodynamics won't bite us in the ass later when cyclical events stop sequestering more heat in the oceans.

text:

Anyway, the real reason we know co2 doesn't drive climate is that there is an few hundred year lag between an increase in temperature and an increase in co2. We find this lag in ice cores and we know exactly why it exists: When temps rise the oceans warm, and warmer water hold less co2 than cold water. So when temps rise co2 is expelled from oceans. It is the temperature driving the co2 not the other way around, this is very clear from ice core records.
author: Jerome Sullivan

text:

"Anyway, the real reason we know co2 doesn't drive climate is that there is an few hundred year lag between an increase in temperature and an increase in co2."

" It is the temperature driving the co2 not the other way around"

This is the same as saying fire can cause kinetic energy therefore kinetic energy cannot cause fire.

It's both, not either/or an initial warming, (usually orbital factors) result in a local warming, since this only results in a certain amount of energy in the system unable to result in a large change to global temperatures it was predicted that positive feedbacks would gradually amplify the small local forcing.

Factors like melting ice revealing a darker surface, increased CO2 production from either the ocean, biological production/decay result in more warming which results in melting and more warming from an initially small forcing.

The mechanism by which CO2 warms is pretty basic, it delays heat dissipation that would normally go out into space which results in more energy in the system for longer periods of time. Just like a blanket doesn't actually warm you it simply delays heat dissipation. The science isn't that complex in this regard.

Small amount of forcing doesn't heat immediately. For example if you put a blow torch on a block of ice it doesn't automatically normalize to the temperature of the blow torch. It takes time, as it warms from (usually) other forcing events, events that result in more warming add on to small forcing events. 

"These loops already assume that co2 will cause warming and as a result will increase water vapor and the water vapor will increase temps. "

This is pretty basic science, CO2 absorbs long wave radiation and reemits it in a random direction delaying heat dissipation. If you wonder if such a thing could result in warmer temperatures that's why I used the blanket analogy. If you wonder if CO2 specifically could do such a thing, there are elementary school projects where you can use baking soda and vinegar to dump CO2 into a bottle and see if it'll be warmer than the bottle without CO2.

I wasn't aware that basic science over 100 years old was that much in question. Water vapor also only increases in concentration for long periods of time if the temperatures warm first. That's that magical thing called rain.

"What if temp starts to fall? Surely you admit this possibility'

Sure, a nuclear winter could happen and block out the sun resulting in a drop in temperatures.

"Would you pump out more co2 if temps took a down-turn?"

Also we already know that a given amount of warming/energy to the system takes a long time to normalize for it's given forcing, even if we stopped all CO2 emissions today it'll continue to warm till it normalizes with the appropriate forcing.

Keep in mind this is the basic energy income, it's not a prediction of future effects, it's essentially a black body calculation based on basic physical properties and physics. What happens as a result is known as sensitivity.

"You can't explain the recent temp pause "

Dimming sun, pollution, volcanic aerosols, comparing it to strongest el nino on record + solar maximum, Oceans are still warming. Already did several times.

" I argue that it is not enough because co2 is a trace gas"

So Ozone, which is even a smaller trace gas has no appreciable effect? It's the same basic principle and your same argument. Sorry, but it's there, it absorbs long wave radiation and delays heat dissipation. This is the case for all ghgs regardless of how trace they are.

"Do you agree with the feedback loops?"

Feedback loops like:
- Melting ice reveals darker terrain which absorb more radiation than white ice.
- Bacteria in melted permafrost produce gases like methane when before they wouldn't because they're frozen.
- temperature sensitive emissions like methane hydrates give off methane as they warm
- Warmer oceans in the long term hold less gas.

What's so hard to agree out of cases like these?

Again, how many times will I have to repeat myself or address your shitty tangents till you will actually defend a point?

text:
+garith21 

PS. my disproof of the significance of 3.7 w/m^2: 
Lets make an Ice sheet, the same volume and surface area of Antarctica then see how long it take 3.7w/m^2 to melt it. 
Latent heat water, Lw = 334kJ/kg
Area of Antarctica, Aa = 14x10^6km^3
Volume of Antarctic ice, Va = 25.5x10^6km^3
Density of water, Dw = 1000kg/m^3
Forcing, F =3.7W/m^2
Mass of Antarctica, Ma = Dw x Va = 25.5x10^18kg
Energy it would take to melt Antarctica, Q = Ma x Lw = 8722x10^21J
Total energy absorption rate, P = Aa x F = 51.8x10^9J/s
Time it would take to melt all Antarctic ice, t = Q/P = 1.68x10^14s 

or about 5,00,000 years!!  feel free to check my work.
We are not as different as you might think. I am an atheist and a non-conservative. A few years ago I would’ve been on your side. Then I heard the arguments of Don Easterbrook, Freeman Dyson and Buzz Aldrin among others. It is undeniable that the skeptical arguments are much stronger than the alarmist arguments. I’m not going to pretend to know how or why such weak arguments have become the status quo.

I don’t think you are stupid. I fell for the hype too.

author: garith21

text:
@Jerome Sullivan 
"PS. my disproof of the significance of 3.7 w/m^2"

The forcing that's a result of milankovitch cycles are .7 w/m^2. Currently you're supposedly operating under the assumption that CO2 and other trace ghgs cannot result in an amplification of this effect. Either this .7 w/m^2 is astronomically stronger than you think it is or positive feedbacks can amplify initial warming.

Also your assumption is that CO2 which is just an initial forcing is the only factor that would be at play....Nothing in geological history or the rest of the physics would indicate this should be the case. Unless you think the energy gained in the system from for example white ice changing to dark blue ocean is zero, positive feedbacks are still factors till you reach thermal equilibrium.

"Volume of Antarctic ice"

Summer or winter ice? Land or sea ice? And why the Antarctic? Your assumption also seems to be that you think that this forcing would apply uniformly. If you read the earlier posts you know this isn't true. For example areas like the poles would warm quicker than the equators because they naturally have a much lower water vapor content, which means less water vapor to compete for those overlapping wavelengths of long wave radiation.

"feel free to check my work."

I'm happy to just grant it as good work, merely the assumptions behind it are flawed.

"Then I heard the arguments of Don Easterbrook, Freeman Dyson and Buzz Aldrin among others."

Well Don Easterbrook has shown to be rather dishonest when you look at original sources and has made vastly wrong predictions. Back in 2008 he said we'd have cooled by as much as 1C from the year 2000, even if you ignore ocean warming, at best from 1998, a time when we know was abnormally high due to short term effects and all of the other cooling effects, it's still not cooling. Dyson Admits he's not an expert in climate (I don't know about you but I think expertise matters, I wouldn't get a dermatologist to do brain surgery simply because he's an expert in something), Buzz Aldrin really doesn't have a background either. I'm not sure why you started with these 3, these would seem like poor examples.

"It is undeniable that the skeptical arguments are much stronger than the alarmist arguments."

Sorry, but going by your arguments so far and the assumptions made in this final proof you simply haven't read the vast body of scientific research or are even aware of what the relevant experts are saying. You even label them as "alarmist" in the same way a creationist labels someone else "evolutionist"...Sorry but you're doing the equivalent of siding with the creationists because you only listened to people like Michael Behe or Kent Hovind. I started off as a skeptic with skeptic arguments and I sought out the answers from relevant experts and peer reviewed papers directly, the skeptics had no response other than to complain about uncertainty and how such things couldn't be predicted, then state how they could predict them with double talk.

When direct correlations break down with standard science they can list the mechanisms and show the measurements or show what assumptions you made that they do not, or what mechanisms you're ignoring that they do not ignore. When this happens with skeptics they say "well the climate is complicated" but then won't even listen to relevant papers that explain the complicated part with relation to the vast majority of relevant experts.

Skeptics don't provide mechanisms for past climate changes when confronted with issues like the forcing from a given orbital change. They don't want to provide mechanisms for this change that can be tested. They don't want to address counter arguments like looking at the Laschamp anomaly and even question if cosmic rays really have as much of an effect as they want to say it does. Skeptics will choose older data particularly in ancient reconstructions in favor of ignoring new ones with better and more sensitive equipment.

"Skeptics" just like creationists assert global scientific conspiracy and when they run out of arguments merely accuse people of fiddling with the data. Sorry, but if you've ever debated a creationist on this topic you have to realize that you're using the same shotgun approach, the same distrust in the vast majority of scientists, the same lack of informed assumptions and this is frankly the first time you've actually tried to defend something you've said, I'll be it on a tangent rather than directly.

P.S. I figured I'd post an old news article from NOAA since this apparently was one of your misc favorite claims. I'm sure I'll just hear a "scientists are just fiddling with the figures" or something like that, but frankly if that's going to be the go to response rather than doing their own experiments to show why the reasoning is poor then I think I'm probably in better company.

http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories2015/noaa-analysis-journal-science-no-slowdown-in-global-warming-in-recent-years.html

century like your “experts” say?"

Well, point out the experts please, point to the sources. The IPCC which most people say is an alarmist organization predicts anywhere from 75cm to 2 metres which is the low end of your claim. By the way, for as much as people say the IPCC is alarmist the trends are tracking with the upper end of their error bars....which indicates they're under estimating sea level rise, but hey who needs facts when you have labels.

If you say "Al Gore" I hope you don't mind if I laugh at you.

Yeah, you're treading the line though, virtually everything you've thrown at me so far I could have gone to a denialist blog. I say denialist because they actually deny facts even when corrected.

"I know you’ve heard “the science is in” with regards to climate;"

Frankly, it's been a question since the 60s and the majority of relevant experts weren't convinced till the mid 90's after the major concerns were addressed with evidence. No one's saying "no more research needs to be done" but it's about as definitive as you can get, the most you can do is quibble about how bad it'll be and how much you'd like to gamble long term prospects to encourage inaction.

"20ft of sea level rise..."

cite your source please

" climate instability are indeed extraordinary claims."

So you don't think the climate is changing significantly?

"You are making the mistake of thinking that it is their job to prove you wrong when the
burden is really on you to prove yourself right."

There's plenty of evidence and observations pointing to the most likely cause of GHGs, I've pointed you towards them this whole conversation, you simply don't want to answer the relevant questions that would make you question your existing narrative.

Specific mechanisms show warming in specific areas quicker, we see the fingerprint that's consistent with GHGs including cases like lower long wave radiation escaping the atmosphere in the bands that ghgs absorb. We even observe the cooling in the upper stratosphere which was predicted long ago. Any one of these observations in a vacuum would be no deal, it's the fact that they all point in the same direction that's relevant. It has passed so many tests in the scientific arena that it qualifies as a theory.

When you confront a case where a testable model has passed the tests and someone else comes by and says "that's not right but I won't say why" it then becomes their burden to explain the phenomenon and propose a better model. No theory is perfect, whether it's general relativity, Evolution or quantum theory, but it takes a lot more than finding possible problems or whining to make it stop from being a theory.

No skeptic wishes to actually challenge this and simply claims fraud, and won't provide mechanisms that are at least consistent with the way it has been warming.

"You haven’t shown me ANYKIND of extraordinary evidence."

Uh, just the requirements of a theory, make predictions based upon a proposed mechanism and confirm it with later observations. If you don't like the scientific method it's on you to provide a better model that represents reality and mechanism that explains the observations in a testable model.

"Again No one knows how climate works just like no-one knows how life started."

no one knows how life started because there's so many venues by which it could have happened and it's impossible to piece together exactly which one it was.

The warming in question occurred in the instrumental record which means if you look at how it's warmed you can test mechanisms. Big difference.

Even if we pretend to hide behind the "no one knows" this doesn't change the fact that an energy imbalance occurred which resulted in more retained heat and things don't happen for no reason, constantly repeating this and then taking no further steps is basically trying to end the conversation like you accused people of doing earlier.

"But they have failed in the past miserably with predictions."

2) If you've actually looked at the predictions they're actually not that far off. It gets far better when you calibrate them with other factors like the increased volcanic activity, the dimming sun, increased pollution and el nino/la nina cycles. (which we know are short term factors)

If you use the "alarmist" IPCC as a standard they've so far under estimated a lot of predictions like ice melt or sea level rise. Most people that assume they've been vastly wrong usually have it first filtered through someone else like Lord Monkton or Watts and never look at the original source.

text:
+garith21 



I don’t think this will convince anyone. Most things like this can’t be disproven. There are things that could convince me, if co2 rose before temperature in the ice-core record, if there had been any significant
warming over the last 15 years as more of the world industrialized; these would be very strong arguments (arguments that I thought were true when I bought into the hype). Computer models don’t do it for me (i have experience with models that deal with heat and chemistry). Aside from the inherent limitations of computers, there are many rates and processes that are poorly understood. It took weather forecasts decades for their predictions to be accurate beyond a week. It will take a long time before we understand climate enough to make predictions 100 years in the future.

Albedo is the ratio of energy reflected to the initial energy. Planetary equilibrium temperature is a function of albedo and irradiance. The average surface absorbs twice as much energy (163.3w/m^2) as the entire
atmosphere above it (77.1w/m^2), energy that is then dumped back into the atmosphere at night (the earth cools more because of its rotation). And the surface changes all the time: foliage, ice, asphalt roads, etc..

I think there is a misconception that only infrared light can heat things up, this is incorrect (have you ever been burned by a green laser? I have.) it is a matter of intensity. Even an ozone molecule is heated up when a uv photon is absorbed. When you look at a solar irradiance absorption spectrum you can clearly see that the highest irradiance per wavelength occurs around 500nm (a dull green). Co2 absorbs radiation further down the spectrum where there is not as much energy but water vapor dominates this area of the spectrum and will always compete with co2. 

No one can say that the warming that occurred between 1977
and 2000 is unprecedented because there was a similar period of warming 30 years prior which was certainly not co2. No one can prove or disprove a statement like, “the warming that occurred between ’77 and ’00 is due to co2”, anymore than you can prove that it was due to Elvis dying in ’77. If you look at a graph of co2 vs temp for this period they do appear to rise together but this DOES NOT MEAN co2 and temp are related, correlation does not imply causation and coincidence cannot be ruled out. It is safe to say that the trends have separated after the start of the 21st century.

Researching this subject is a nightmare. There are people who have, no doubt, been caught doctoring graphs like Shaun Marcott and Richard Muller among a few others. No doubt there are those on the skeptics side injecting speculative and untrue information as well, I have seen them while researching this. I think this is why both sides have lost faith in eachother. Many sites and sources give completely true information but they will pick and choose periods of time that support their arguments like the '77-'00 period. This thing is a circus and a perfect example of why politics and science don’t mix.

I am not saying humans can’t be a significant factor in climate, but I am saying it there is no reason to think co2 is a major threat based on empirical evidence. To boot, much of the last 10,000 years has been warmer. Google "temperature last 10000 years" to see what i mean. There have been periods of faster warming for longer periods of time in the not so distant past. 

 


 

The reason m-cycles effect the climate appears to be the changes in albedo that result. The following is how my professor explained to me, I used his lectures as a source, It is not obvious until you hear it:

The earth does not orbit in a perfect circle, rather, it orbits in an ellipse with an eccentricity of 0.0167 (current). The difference in irradiance between apogee and perigee (a result of greater distance from the sun at apogee) is about 2.0w/m^2.  The approximate fraction of that is absorbed by the atmosphere is 0.7w/m^2. That is what that number refers to and that is accurate for the atmosphere but the surface of the earth is different….

Because of Kepler’s laws, a planet spends more time at apogee than perigee and remember the earth is tilted. So, sometimes the northern
hemisphere is pointed toward the sun (summer) when earth is at perigee
resulting in short super-summers. At those same times the northern hemisphere is pointed away at apogee resulting in long super-winters. Meanwhile the opposite hemisphere has long cool summers and short mild winters. Currently, perigee is in July (near the peak of summer) so the northern hemisphere is the one experiencing the super-seasons at the moment.

These short super-summers and long super-winters don’t effect the atmosphere that much because the atmosphere is more/less uniform. The
surface, however, is not. There is much more land mass in the northern hemisphere than in the southern hemisphere. The south pole has a continent almost twice as big as Australia centered at the pole while the north pole has no land mass there at all (military submarines can pop through the seasonal sea ice there). The net result is that the hemispheres have a different capacity to hold ice, the result of this is that the albedo of the earth changes depending on which hemisphere is getting the super-seasons. The case is really even more complicated than this and there are still unknowns. The earths eccentricity changes as it interacts with other planets and these effects are more pronounced when eccentricity is high (range: 0.06-0.005) M-cycles are some of the dominant factors over timescales of 10s of thousands and hundreds of thousands of years, they don’t appear to effect things on shorter timescales. 

I'll give you the last word garith.

Paleoclimactic records also indicate that the initial triggers for leaving cases like snowball earth required CO2 rising first. Particularly since even today's solar activity wouldn't be able to break out a completely ice covered earth.

Ironically people who don't know about this like to do stuff like take snap shots when CO2 concentrations were really high at the end of snow ball earth and ask "If CO2 was so high, how did we have mile high ice at the equator". "and will always compete with co2. "
Actually it'll only compete in cases where they do overlap, there's plenty where it doesn't, not to mention there are many areas where there is less water vapor which is why CO2 has a greater effect in those areas. Already been over this.

"because there was a similar period of warming 30 years prior which was certainly not co2"

" There are people who have, no doubt, been caught doctoring graphs like Shaun Marcott and Richard Muller "

I even see skeptics claiming that BEST proves global warming is false, even though BEST seems to indicate no such thing.

I don't know much of Marcott's work, but my understanding is that it's still in good standing with the scientific community

"'77-'00 period. This thing is a circus and a perfect example of why politics and science don’t mix."

Well the 77-today discussion is primarily when temperatures rise out of natural noise where natural markers and models start disagreeing and only seem to agree when you take into account carbon based gases as a factor. Despite skeptics accusing proponents of fudging numbers to match the observations they can't seem to make models that recreate past observations without including GHGs even though they should be able to do exactly the same thing.

"Currently, perigee is in July (near the peak of summer) so the northern hemisphere is the one experiencing the super-seasons at the moment."

I should also point out that a lot of the mechanisms you're proposing would only explain local warming, it wouldn't explain how it could spread through the rest of the globe which is exactly what the GHG mechanisms were supposed to explain because it would only result in a local warming without them.

Well on top of the fact that your proposed mechanism are completely ignoring the fingerprints of ghg based warming that have been observed I'll give you a hint of why we know this isn't the primary factor at play right now.

How long does it take for this difference to take place? Hint, it's longer than the century and you even know this because it's one of the last things you said.

"M-cycles are some of the dominant factors over timescales of 10s of thousands and hundreds of thousands of years, they don’t appear to effect things on shorter timescales."

text:
Because many of the other associated effects of climate change like more severe droughts/floods/effects on pest behavior tend to make such practices more difficult. While you could technically move such facilities to more suitable lands as it gets worse in those areas. The problem is that many places where the economy is centered around that will simply lose out and eventually such production will be sent to places where they don't get as much sun light even if it ends up being better for the stable local climate you'll be reducing the usable land in current areas in favor of areas with less direct light for photosynthesis.

While it's interesting to wonder what's the case, even if you only used common sense that would dictate that you'll have long term issues particularly if we don't change our behaviors the issues merely compound on something that takes a while to normalize. With regards to the science, while many disagree on the potential costs, the vast majority indicate that more than likely it would simply be more expensive in the long term to ignore it than to address it because of the compounding problems which reach well beyond the food supply.

text:
"In your opinion, what caused the Medieval Warm Period"

Orbital factors that take hundreds if not thousands of years to occur.

"And what caused the Little Ice Age, which ended at about the time the American Civil War was being fought?"

An abundant amount of sulfuric aerosols which reflected sunlight back into space. Orbital factors were also at play but they were very minor at a rate around -.02C/century. During the middle of the lia there was also a major decrease in solar activity which amplified the already massive cooling from increased volcanic activity which released more aerosols.

"How do these two climate events compare to the climate change you've seen during your lifetime?"

with regards to time scale, pretty insignificant in comparison to today. I mean skeptics often claim that .1C/decade (the current rate) is not a big deal but when you look at averages that it took to get to the medieval warm period that took hundreds of years to achieve what took a few decades today. The Medieval warm period was also pretty cool in comparison to today.

The LIA was only a .4C drop from conditions previous to it and that took a few hundred years as well. This is assuming you're using the most extreme reconstructions and not the average reconstructions for that time period.

In all reality, I don't know why someone claiming to be a skeptic would even ask this question which is quite easy to verify yourself.

text:
+Fuzzy2U Fuzzy2U
Do you follow science at all? It has nothing to do with ego, and everything to do with the scientific facts that scientific research has obtained.

Earth's greenhouse gasses are naturally at an equilibrium. By introducing the large amount of greenhouse gases into the environment in a short frame of time it completely destabilizes this equilibrium. The heating effect of the gas causes more water to evaporate into the atmosphere, which in turn causes the Earth to heat even more. This cycle is called positive feedback, and is a mechanism where smaller changes can end up causing significantly larger changes.

Volcanoes only account for only around 1% of current greenhouse gas increases, so I think you're underestimating the way things are. That's the problem when you guess instead of rely on science.

text:
How to Win The Climate Change Debate Every time
            There are many common beliefs about what climate change actually is. This is a problem that is specific to this current generation due to the technological advances that are supposedly the cause. There is a high amount of activism going on about stopping man-made climate change, but I'm going to show you why this is a waste of time. Climate change and global warming are not the same things.
Let's look at the definitions. Based on Global Warming the unabridged guide..."Global Warming is the rise in the average temperature of Earth's atmosphere and oceans since the late 19th century and it's projected continuation." This rise in temperature is due to the activities of humans and that is from a 95% consensus from scientist on a U.N. panel. In short the definition of global warming is that the actions of humans are causing the earth to get hotter and it will eventually lead to the end of the earth. It is not the same thing as climate change. Climate change is something that has been going on since the beginning of time. It is the natural fluctuation of the earth's climate. We don't have any control of it. For example, who cause who caused the ice age? Was it the dinosaurs? Who brought us out of the ice age? Was it the first human settlers that caused the earth to thaw by their smoke signal and camp fires harming the ozone layer? If you think about if longer than two minutes you will realize it's not likely.
The first claim I will debunk is this. Cow flatulence is causing the Ozone later to open and cause global warming. Many of you may feel this is just a ridiculous claim that I am making up. If only that was the case. The White House wants to regulate cow farts. Vaccines are even being developed to decrease the amount of greenhouse gases(cattle flatulence) being emitted. Australian farmers are even signing their sheep and cattle up to get vaccinated for this purpose.
Let's use common sense. If cow or cattle flatulence is so dangerous to this planet, what happened when the dinosaurs were around? Dinosaurs are said to have roamed the planet for 165 million years. Over the span of 165 million years you can safely figure that the accumulated population of dinosaurs exceeds that of cows and other cattle of this present time. You can also safely figure that dinosaurs are multiple times more massive than cows and any other animal on this planet. We could look at the recent discovery of the Titanosaurus for reference. This is said to be the largest animal to ever walk the planet. The point is that the dinosaurs would have emitted more greenhouse gases than cows due to their gargantuan size. They also would have emitted more gas over a time of 165 million years. According to the original claim this should have caused many massive holes in the ozone layer. As you can see the earth is not a ball of flames, and not only that but we had an ice age. We should have had an extremely hot age with those high amount of global warming causing factors.But we did not. Simply put, the ice age we had was natural climate change. This climate change happens without the actions of humans. Another point you must consider is how we left the ice age, surely is was not because of the camp fires of settlers emitting gases into the ozone later.
The second claim is that human caused global warming is causing the polar bears to almost go extinct. The idea is that global warming is melting the polar ice caps and is destroying their environment. This is causing them to die and even eat one another. The polar bear has been the mascot for the cause of global warming for many years but when looking at the numbers, the claims do not add up. In the 1950's it was reported that there are 5,000 to 10,000 living polar bears in the world. In the year 2014, it is reported that there are 22,600 to 32,000 living polar bears on the planet. That is four times the amount from the 1950's. As far as their habitat is concerned, in 2007 Al Gore spoke intensely about scientific research he had seen and predicted the entire north polar ice caps will vanish. If we look at the data from 2013 we actually see that the polar ice caps are still there and they have increased from the last year.
The third claim is that we actually have to take action to stop global warming. There are billions of dollars being spent and solution being created to stop global warming. Politicians are making speeches about going green by using wind and solar power so we can cut down carbon emissions. This sounds nice and I would love to have every home powered by solar panels but if this is solely because of global warming then there is a problem. Global warming has been on a 17 years plus pause. According to NASA it's been for 17 years and six months. If we bring it up to date we see its been 17 years and nine months. This is startling information considering the growth of the population. More people means more carbon emissions going into the atmosphere. That means we should see more global warming. More global warming would bring a hotter earth  and we would see a continuous increase in temperature every year. That has not been the case with this 17 year pause. We also have more cars on the road than ever. According to a study by Wards Auto, the population of cars on the road is over one Billion. We see an increase in global warming causing factors, but no increase in temperature. If you haven't noticed, we have experienced record-breaking cold temperatures recently around the world. For example, it recently snowed in Egypt for the first time in 112 years.

text:
The natural processes don't actually contribute much to the warming, but the introduction of formerly sequestered carbon in the form of fossil fuels definitely does. Yes, farming and ranching practices are going to change the climate, but mostly because they employ serious quantities of fossil fuels.. it's with that source of energy that ranchers can keep as many cattle, sheep, chickens, and pigs enclosed in tiny cages as they legally can. Remove the fossil fuels, and people around the world starve. 

Eliminate all use of fossil fuels and the Keeling curve plateaus - and natural processes will begin the very slow chemistry of removing the excess CO2 from the air and ocean.

The only solution I see for our current state is the one employed by Governor Kodos.
author: Rand Huso

text:
+Max Othing Methane is a greenhouse gas, but it makes up only a negligable factor of the atmosphere. It has almost no effect. Deforestation is of course bad, but because of the raised CO2 levels, the rainforests have benefited hugely. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere by the way, are only 7% due directly to human emissions. The rest is natural, or the result of out-gassing. When the temperature warms soil and water release CO2 into the atmosphere. The current warning tend started long before humans began to pump CO2 into the atmosphere, and that was right after a period of cooling. 

Ocean acidity is quite low even as it is with all the CO2. 

The whole debate regarding greenhouse gases is that since CO2 and to a very small extent methane slightly heats the water, and causes more water vapour to evaporate into the atmosphere (the main greenhouse gas) this year's the planet even more, and more water evaporates and so on and so forth. Most climate models (which are usually wrong) use this feedback system as the only factor in climate change. This is a logical fallacy, as there are many positive and negative feedbacks involved which cancel eachother out. Amongst all of this, methane is almost a non-factor, and I have never come across a single article of paper or scientist that says it is.
author: ENiGMA

text:
@ENiGMA 

Here's one: http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v443/n7107/abs/nature05040.html
Here's another: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012825201000629
Or what about: http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-011-0061-5

There's three. I could find lots more for you if you needed. However, I suspect that you just haven't looked.

As for our CO2 contribution to the atmosphere - consider this: we've pumped up and largely burned 1.4 trillion barrels of oil. Each barrel is 42 US gallons. Most of this becomes fuel of some sort and is burned (about 95%). This combustion produced enough CO2 to increase the atmospheric CO2 amount by 83 ppmv. You can do the same calculations for natural gas and coal - and it quite clearly shows that human use of fossil fuels is the prime factor in increasing our atmospheric CO2.

This is also confirmed by an analysis of the C14 isotope concentration in the atmosphere which has declined considerably. C14 is not found in fossil fuels, indicating the CO2 increase in the atmosphere is from formerly sequestered carbon, and not from the current carbon cycle.

text:
+AlwaysSoldierOn This sentiment s so silly I usually joke about it.  I'll point to a field or some sort of organic waste that no human would touch or couldn't even digest...and say, "Gee, it sure would be swell if there was some kind of process or machine that could turn that inedible garbage into food people would like, possibly even love."


Of course, that's because I know that that's just what domestic farm animals are.  And BTW, many of the claims of animals being fed by grain are not entirely accurate.  They're double counting (especially in the US).  Because the government is subsidizing grain alcohol (to burn in cars...see, THAT is something we'd have to stop), there's a bunch of this high protein, easily digested goop left over called "mash".  That is fed to various farm animals because it would otherwise go to waste.  Yes there is grain fed to cattle...but the numbers are often counting this goop that no human would touch and it would be more accurate to say that our cars were fed this grain and that feeding the goop to animals was the only way to salvage any of it as food.  And let's not forget that animals can graze on land that can't be farmed.


So it's really just another part of the vast web of misinformation spewed by the more overzealous members of the environmental movement...little more than an assumption born of ignorance.  Using reasonable methods, it makes good sense to farm domestic animals and good sense to have meat in your diet.

text:
+AlwaysSoldierOn
Not true at all.
1. Eggs, fish, honey, and insects could easily be quite sustainable at current population levels.
2. In addition, population levels could decrease over time resulting in more flexibility for per-capita emissions.
3. The amount a person consumes is ultimately what decides if something is sustainable, not whether they consume it at all (unless something is 100% non-renewable)\
4. If combustion and calcination rates continued to escalate, emissions from those sources would still be a major problem to contribute to the greenhouse effect regardless of what the agricultural emissions were at.

 What these points mean —and ignoring the last one— is that people will have to —or should— be consuming significantly less large animal meats such as Cow, Pig, Bison, Deer/Caribou, Kangaroo, and Ostrich. In addition, it also means not allowing too many animals to live in the wild. If everyone was vegan and noone killed any animals, they could eventually grow to such large populations where they could grow in environmental impact. Examples would be creatures such as rabbits, bison, geese, seals, and deer, which don't have much or any significant amount of predators in many of their main environments.
author: Mshojat

text:
@MsHojat  Adding (and bringing it up again) You have to remember that the whole "sustainability" thing is a bit of a dodge in real life.  What are we going to run out of?  Basically...fossil fuels, and they'll be around for about a lifetime more at least.

Everything else is already renewable or just mineral...and we won't run out of minerals in any practical sense.  The same is true of energy, it takes 5-10X the materials, labor, and maintenance for renewables.  It makes absolutely no sense at this time given the absurd abundance of nuclear fuel, and the fact that it would take 1/5-1/10 the materials, labor, and maintenance of renewables like wind/solar.

And ironically, we don't need to put the world on some crazy energy rationing scheme, quite the contrary.  The best way out, for man AND the environment...is through.  Only when nations have fully developed do their environments clean up like they have in the developed world.  And there's enough fission material alone to provide US per capita consumption for 8 billion people for 10000 years...and I'm pretty darned sure somewhere in there we'd figure out fusion.

Essentially all of these alarmist energy/sustainability talking points you seen in the news today are worthless garbage...academic answers that are "technically correct" yet essentially wrong right now.

author: Maximus Asauluk

text:
+iAM_TeNKo
1. The sun has been monitored and studied for quite some time, and no indication has been seen of an increase.
2. Suns operate at timescales which are vastly beyond those of which humans operate; any changes which occur would be so slow they'd be of no significance to humans at all (at least over thousands of years).
3. The greenhouse effect is a scientifically verified phenomenon, and gasses such as CO2 and CH4 are verified to have a significant greenhouse effect. Much of the gasses being released are not gases from a natural cycle, but rather which have been trapped in other molecular states for a long period of time, and were not previously in the atmosphere (at least for a very long time). By releasing a large amount of such gasses into the environment, it causes a destabilization of the equilibrium, and could cause a significant change as a consequence.

Related to your question is how do people know that it's not something such as Earth's varying orbit (procession/etc.); that has been monitored as well, and has been ruled out. Based off such cycles Earth should actually be cooling (some deniers claim that it should be warming based off such cycles, but I have no idea where they are getting information that supports such a claim).
author: Mshojat

text:
@***** 
Not quite. Recent research shows there's a limit to how much CO2 plants can use, and what we'd call weeds tolerate higher levels. And past times with higher levels of CO2 must also be compared to solar output at the same time, as well as our position in the Milanković cycles, and other biological and physical processes. Life flourishing in the presence of elevated amounts of CO2 may correlate positively, but causation isn't conclusive.

text:
+Angela Davis (Youtre1995)
"Climate change and global warming are not the same things."
Climate Change is the scientific term, global warming is the colloquial term for non scientists to describe what generally happens.


"Let's use common sense."
Common sense isn't how science is done, also, common sense isn't particularly common


"This rise in temperature is due to the activities of humans and that is from a 95% consensus from scientist on a U.N. panel."
Incorrect, the consensus is derived from the current peer reviewed literature and is over 95% of the scientific community.


"Dinosaurs are said to have roamed the planet for 165 million years."
You do realize we have a very different climate from then right? There were times in earth's history where sea levels were 200 feet higher, it doesn't mean that it's something we should be working towards.


"This climate change happens without the actions of humans."
Past climate change is usually primarily due to orbital factors that result in initial releases of ghgs which change local warming/cooling into global warming/cooling, but even this tends to take tens of thousands of years to change temperatures on a global basis by large swings baring large events like asteroid impacts or super volcano eruptions.


"in 2007 Al Gore spoke intensely about scientific research he had seen and predicted the entire north polar ice caps will vanish. If we look at the data from 2013 we actually see that the polar ice caps are still there and they have increased from the last year."
Uh, did they have any prediction when it would vanish? As far as I know the peer reviewed literature indicated that summer sea ice in the arctic would be gone somewhere in the next 20-30 years, the IPCC predicted not till the end of the century. Winter ice in the Arctic will be there for the foreseeable future, but if you've seen live streams of the north pole during the summer it's actually been more like the north pool for the last few years.


" In the 1950's it was reported that there are 5,000 to 10,000 living polar bears in the world. In the year 2014, it is reported that there are 22,600 to 32,000 living polar bears on the planet."
According to? I'd also be more inclined to think that this is primarily due to the difference in detection techniques since we're much better at finding/counting things now than we were in the 50's.



"Global warming has been on a 17 years plus pause."

Except it's not, first of all this claim usually starts around 1998 which is very much not an average year as it was one of the strongest el nino's in recorded history and it was near a time of a solar maximum. These two events are among the strongest short term events that can swing surface temperatures. The proper question to ask when confronted with this is "why are current temperatures regardless of those factors on par with that double event without those factors?" IE why is that the new norm for temperatures?


Secondly the vast amount of warming is occurring in the oceans and is decidedly not on a pause.


"More global warming would bring a hotter earth  and we would see a continuous increase in temperature every year."
Hotter globally is exactly what we're seeing, but you're looking in places where it's much more variant based on other factors and ignoring where most of the warming currently is and also cherry picking starting points with other factors causing natural variance to be unusually high and insisting that should be the new average.


Secondly there are other various factors at play contributing to cooling like more sulfates being produced by volcanoes, greater pollution resulting in less sunlight reaching the earth's surface which decreases the amount of long wave radiation that ghgs have to work on and the fact that the sun has been less active over the last 50 years.

The science of ghgs are pretty basic, more ghgs result in less heat dissipation for a given amount of long wave radiation. If you increase the concentration it reduces the heat dissipation, if you reduce the amount of long wave radiation you reduce the temperatures. Despite all of the factors contributing to cooling we're still seeing global surface temperatures on par with 1998, why is that? Magic?

"If you haven't noticed, we have experienced record-breaking cold temperatures recently around the world. For example, it recently snowed in Egypt for the first time in 112 years."


First, the vast majority of record breaking is in the warming direction, secondly we're talking about climate, not weather. This is like saying a desert stops being a desert the day it floods. No one in the scientific community ever predicted "no more cold records" merely that the ratio of cold temperatures to hot temperatures will shift more towards the hot temperatures on average.


Lastly copy/pasting is very much not impressive and it may indicate you know very little on the topic you espouse to care about.

			 And many economist believe real GDP growth in the U.S. has been closer to zero % and maybe even negative in recent years,  governments have a way of manipulating the data, and with all of the money printing "quantitative easing" its hard to measure true GDP.  Food stamp usage is at an all time high at about 47 million Americans and total unemployment which is unemployment plus those whom have given up on finding a job is at about 94 million Americans, this is also an all time high. 
China's GDP growth rate has averaged 10% over the last 30 years and has slowed down to just over 7% this year.
 http://www.wsj.com/articles/china-third-quarter-gdp-slows-to-7-3-growth-1413857081
So, can you grow your GDP and lower your emissions at the same time?  Maybe!  As technology improves yes!  But right now world wide emissions are growing rapidly.  I think the main reason we have been able to somewhat lower our emissions here in the states is because 55 thousand of our manufacturing companies since 2000 have moved their facilities out of the country!

text:
@*****  
"Even the International convention 
on climate change admitted that if we stopped all Co2 output, we'd only 
effect the climate by maybe 1 degree over a century"

Lets assume this is true, Assuming you know anything about the science you'd be aware that because of how long it takes for oceans to respond to an initial forcing you'd expect it to continue to warm for hundreds of years. I don't see how this is an issue.

"which is within natural parameters."

Globally not so much, particularly over the time period. While local and hemispheric changes can occur pretty quickly. Temperature changes we're seeing usually take thousands if not tens of thousands of years rather than under a century barring large climactic events.

" The new satellite data has shown all of the models to be wrong"

Except not, it's indicating a lowered amounts of long wave radiation escaping the atmosphere which is how CO2 based warming works. It indicates a cooling of the upper stratosphere which is what you would expect from CO2 based warming.

I'm sorry but judging from the fact you copy n pasted this in at least 2 of my posts indicates you're just parroting without understanding the topic.
author: garith21

text:
@***** 
"It's exactly why I'm pasting it. It's to spread the point."

You're demonstrating ignorance and spreading it widely, not something I'd personally choose, but that's your perogative.

" The models are completely slanted"

Which models? I ask because I hear this claim a lot but no one ever wants to point to sources because then they can be proved wrong in this assertion.

" And what temperature changes are you referring to? "

With the sun cooling you'd expect it to cool, even if you cherry pick at best for a skeptic cause it's little to no change for land data if you ignore updated estimations.

The vast majority of the warming is occurring in the upper layers of the oceans however which isn't in question.

"Also, the science on co2 based warming/cooling effects on diferent layers of the atmosphere has been up in the air (pardon the pun) for a long time.. they still can't seem to agree on it."

Uh no, it's basic thermodynamics, greater CO2 in the lower atmosphere leaves less long wave radiation for the upper layers of the atmosphere which is why it would cause more warming in the lower troposphere and cooling in the upper stratosphere which is what we observe.

It's also why we see observations like it's warming at night as much as the day, it's warming at northern latitudes more quickly than the equator.

CO2 has particular fingerprints that have been observed as the dominant phenomenon, you should at least be willing to provide a mechanism by how it's warming to be tested rather than apparently thinking that "ABCD" anything but carbon dioxide is a valid response and also apparently thinking that the temperatures would then change by magic.

text:
@*****  please do.

And it's not mud slinging, it's pointing out that you don't understand topics well because of how you're arguing.

When stating that temperatures will continue to increase even if we stopped all emissions today. That's expected. It's like stepping on the gas while driving, then taking your foot off the gas and being perplexed at why the car is still going. Just as one example.

Based on what we've already put into the atmosphere we'd expect for this to happen and we wouldn't expect it to stabilize for a few centuries since we know the deep oceans take a long time to respond to surface temperatures.

How do we know this? Well remember that 800 year lag time that most skeptics will point to while proclaiming that CO2 is caused by increased temperatures while simultaneously ignoring it's properties to absorb and reemit long wave radiation in a random direction. author: garith21

text:
@***** 
"there have been times where the PPM was over 4000, Life thrived just fine."

Yeah, and when sea levels were 500 meters higher....if you think this is a good thing I'd have to question why.

"The Earth has natural mechanisms for cooling itself.. It's done it literally 100's of times"

Not by magic, most cases it's orbital forcing, but that wont be a factor for a few thousand years and it's orders of magnitudes less of an energy change than putting more CO2 in the atmosphere.

There's also the sun, which has been dimmer since more or less the turn of the century, but we're strangely not cooling and the physics indicates that even if we went through another maunder minimum that it might bring us back to the mid 90's with regards to short term temperatures and spike back up when the solar cycle returns to normal.

"there hasn't been any climate change for over 20 years now, and the the argument is simply getting old."

Oh get your cherry picking right you need to go to 1997 so you include 1998 which is a year that had the strongest el nino on record coupled with a near solar maximum. A few years more you get an upwards trend, a few years less and you get an upwards trend, you have to have that abnormal year be the beginning of your trend to make your argument, no more or no less.

Please just ignore the fact that this is only land temperatures to and ignore that sea surface temperatures have been increasing as well.

"If man made climate change was so obvious, there wouldn't be a debate. It would just be "it is" but it's not a simple science, and the proof is waning, and not really convincing."

As far as science is concerned, it's pretty settled physics. The debate is political not really scientific, with that respect there's about as much debate as there is with evolution.
author: garith21

text:
@***** 
" The water levels have never been 500 meters higher... You could melt every bit of ice on Earth and it would never reach that high..  70 meters at most..  that's a bit irrelevant though. It's just a bit more dramatic than what is possible."

The primary mechanism isn't melted ice it's thermal expansion, and yes there was a time when they were that high.

" Volcanoes have pumped way more Co2 at times in history than we will ever reach driving cars."

Well if you're talking about all of history sure, on a yearly basis we produce well over 130 times more than all the worlds volcanoes combined and even that's an underestimation because the study for that was done like 6 years ago.

Besides there's natural sequestration, the whole point is that we emit so much that we outrun natural sequestration which lead to build ups every year which lead to large changes from collective small changes not "humans produce all the CO2 and it's destroying the earth"

" We are currently rising in orbital forcing temperature. and getting close to the peak time. This is a force of your own mentioning, yet its actually on my side in this case."

Actually no, it won't be a significant factor for thousands of years. I'd be curious why this would cause tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling when orbital forces that cause warming take thousands to tens of thousands of years to occur is puzzling to me.

I'd also be curious as to why temperatures tracked pretty well with solar activity for most of the last 200 years and the first half of the century, but suddenly orbital forcing supposedly kicked in parts of the last half century to the point that solar activity doesn't track well with solar forcing any more.

" The sun is dimmer and hence we arent warming....
Well, we were warming before that, and at a rather normal rate.. so It is quite possible that it will return to normal, and continue our climb out of an ice age, which will heat oceans, and release more Co2.. until it hits terminal equalibrium. It will then start to fall again, as it has before."

Strange that temperatures track fairly well with the sun till recent years and now you're saying it's got a lag time on surface temperatures when it suits you. With the dimmer sun if you expected no other factors were significant you'd expect cooling, but we're not cooling and unless you cherry pick really hard we've still been warming.

"yes, and this generates an average which is used when dealing with weather spikes. A hard El nino comes about every 11 years.. thats kind of unavoidable."

Well if you account for the el nino, the trend's pretty easy to see. If you don't cherry pick the strongest el nino near a solar maximum to start your claim it's pretty easy to see.

If I said It's been warming for 17 years since it's right before a very strong la nina you'd presumably say I was being dishonest, why can't you apply the same reasoning to sticking the strongest el nino at the beginning of your trend?
